text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
daikon with irish tea cake that's right

the only thing worse than trying a new
twist on a recipe and not having to come

out is trying a new twist on a recipe
and having no idea if it came out which

is basically what happened here but
anyway we'll deal with my confusion

later for now let's just proceed as if
everything went according to plan and by

the way this is not just called irish
tea cake because it's great with tea

that's also called that because tea is
one of the key ingredients which is why

we're gonna start this operation by
brewing up a couple cups and in case

you're keeping score at home I'm using
an Irish Breakfast tea which is a black

tea and after pouring a couple cups of
boiling water over a couple bags I let

that steep for about five minutes before
giving it a squeeze and then what we'll

do is let that cool down until it's just
barely warm at which point we'll use

that to soak our dried fruit in and the
dried fruit I decided to go with for

this loaf with some currants some dried
sour cherries and some golden raisins

but of course for something like this
any dried fruits gonna work so use what

you want
I mean you are for all the quarterback

of your barmbrack which by the way is
the ancient Irish name of the fruit loaf

this recipe is based on but anyway no
matter what you use we're gonna go ahead

and pour our warm tea over and we'll
simply let that sit out for a couple

hours at which point it should look a
little something like this alright that

fruits gonna rehydrate and plump up
nicely and not only did I strain this to

use the fruit for the batter I also
reserved some of the liquid to use in

there as well which may or may not have
been a mistake

but anyway that's how we're gonna prep
our fruit and then the other thing we

should prep ahead of time is our loaf
pan and all that means is generously

buttering it and possibly put it in a
piece of parchment to make it easier to

lift out okay that's optional and the
loaf will probably come out anyway but

when cooking it never hurts to hedge
your bets and then once those things are

set we can move on to the actual cake
and that will start by bringing together

our dry ingredients beginning with two
kinds of flour all-purpose and I'm using

some spelt flour which is by far my
favorite whole grain flour but just

regular whole wheat flour would work and
then to that we're gonna add some salt

as well as some baking powder follow
by some very classic fruit loaf spices

which means a generous amount of
cinnamon as well as some freshly grated

nutmeg that I freshly grated ahead of
time we will also want a little kiss of

ginger as well as a little hint of
ground clove and that is going to be it

for our dry stuff but before we let any
wet stuff near this we're gonna take a

whisk and give it a mix to make sure
everything's broken up and evenly

distributed and then once that's been
accomplished we can move on to adding

our wet ingredients so we will go ahead
and make a well in the center which I

really don't think has much of a
practical purpose but it seems like

something we should do and then into
that we will add some brown sugar as

well as one large whole egg which you
can tell is a good one because the yolk

is orange and then we will also want to
splash a whole milk as well as a couple

tablespoons of our reserved tea from
soaking the fruit and then a lot of the

recipes called for candied orange and
lemon rind but I didn't have that so I

just used freshly grated lemon in orange
zest and it seemed to work out nicely

and then we'll go ahead and Irish this
up with a little splash of whiskey he

said possibly inappropriately as well as
a few drops of vanilla and then last but

not least we will pour in a whole bunch
of melted butter and then we will take a

spatula and give this a mix but not all
the way because we still need to add our

strained tea soaked dried fruit so what
we'll do is mix this until it's about

75% of the way which is kind of an
annoying instruction because how the

heck do you tell well you don't you just
mix it until it looks like this where

that flour is almost but not quite fully
incorporated and what we'll do at that

point is stop right there and add our
fruit and then we'll continue stirring

this until that's just mixed in and if
you're thinking that looks like a lot of

fruit it really was but what I was
attempting to do here was make a tea

cake that was extra fruity and dense and
moist and so I thought by adding a ton

of that soaked fruit along with some of
that reserved tea it would help me

achieve that goal and his sort of did
but as you'll see there were trade offs

but anyway once that's mix we'll go
ahead and transfer that into our loaf

pan and we'll make sure that spread out
as evenly as possible and in hindsight I

probably should have made more batter
since this only came like halfway up the

pan but I really thought this was gonna
rise as it baked which as you'll see it

really didn't as in like not at all but
anyway I transferred that in and spread

it out and of course gave it the old tap
etapa to help settle the batter but also

for good luck and that's it I went ahead
and transfer that into the center of a

325 degree oven for about 45 minutes
until my loaf was firm and a toothpick

came out clean which I didn't film but
he did and I remember thinking to myself

as I pulled this out that does not look
good right it didn't rise and because it

was so low in the pan the top didn't get
any color but then I remembered the tops

of these get brushed with honey while
they're still hot so I went ahead and

drizzled some over and brushed it down
and that did improve the appearance a

little bit so I was feeling a little
better plus I assumed that once it's

cooled down and I sliced in the inside
was gonna look beautiful but it didn't

it actually looked worse but anyway I'm
getting ahead of myself since once this

had cooled before I sliced in I went
ahead and garnish the top with some

blood orange zest as well as some bloody
word slices since I had those around and

they are so beautiful so I went ahead
and added a little visual distraction to

the top before grabbing the wrong knife
and slice it in alright it was too short

and that serrated edge kind of grabbed
and pulled the fruit but anyway I sliced

in and did not like what I saw
alright it's never a good sign when

something looks exactly the same cooked
as it did when it went into the pan Plus

that grayish brown color isn't exactly
what we call appetizing so at this point

I was thinking this was going to be a
complete failure but then I took a bite

and got really confused because the
texture was actually surprisingly

Pleasant and the flavor was excellent I
mean like really good and then I

remembered you're supposed to spread
some butter on this so I did and it

tasted even better alright that black
tea we used to soak the fruit gives us

such a unique flavor and despite its
very odd appearance it really was

delicious to eat and to prove it I
finished that slice and then cut another

one with a straight edged knife which
worked a lot better

although the slice kind of looked the
same but anyway I spread some butter on

that one as well and continued eating
and being confused

so to summarize I really don't know what
to make of this attempt at barmbrack I

mean on one hand like I said it was
delicious and the flavors were beautiful

and for lack of a better description it
was kind of like a fresh fruitcake and

really would be perfect with a cup of
hot tea for breakfast but on the other

hand it didn't rise and was really flat
and if we're being honest to not look

that attractive so I'll just finish by
saying I really think we all learned

something here today I'm just not sure
what that is

so unlike most videos I really can't say
whether I hope you give this a try soon

but if you do head over to food wishes
dot-com for all the ingredient amounts
of more info as usual and as always
you
